title: Psalms Chapter 47 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 47 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 47 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 47.

questions.question: According to Psalms 47:1, what are all people instructed to do?
questions.correctAnswer: Clap your hands
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:1 instructs all people to clap their hands and shout unto God with the voice of triumph.

questions.question: Who is described as a great King over all the earth in Psalms 47:2?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD most high
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:2 states that the LORD most high is a great King over all the earth.

questions.question: What will God do to the nations according to Psalms 47:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Subdue them under us
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:3 says God shall subdue the people and nations under us and under our feet.

questions.question: What has God chosen for us as mentioned in Psalms 47:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Our inheritance
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:4 states that God shall choose our inheritance, the excellency of Jacob whom He loved.

questions.question: According to Psalms 47:5, how has God gone up?
questions.correctAnswer: With a shout
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:5 says God is gone up with a shout and the LORD with the sound of a trumpet.

questions.question: What are we instructed to do repeatedly in Psalms 47:6?
questions.correctAnswer: Sing praises
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:6 commands to sing praises to God, sing praises unto our King, sing praises.

questions.question: Why should we sing praises with understanding according to Psalms 47:7?
options: Because God is the King of all the earth
questions.correctAnswer: Because God is the King of all the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:7 explains that God is the King of all the earth and we should sing praises with understanding.

questions.question: Where does God sit according to Psalms 47:8?
options: Upon the throne of his holiness
questions.correctAnswer: Upon the throne of his holiness
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:8 states that God sitteth upon the throne of his holiness.

questions.question: Who are gathered together in Psalms 47:9?
questions.correctAnswer: The princes of the people
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:9 states that the princes of the people are gathered together, the people of the God of Abraham.

questions.question: According to Psalms 47:9, to whom do the shields of the earth belong?
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:9 says the shields of the earth belong unto God, who is greatly exalted.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 47:2 describes the LORD as a terrible king.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:2 says the LORD most high is terrible and a great King over all the earth.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 47:5 says God went up with the sound of a trumpet.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:5 states God is gone up with a shout, the LORD with the sound of a trumpet.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 47:7 tells us to sing praises without understanding.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:7 instructs to sing praises with understanding because God is the King of all the earth.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 47:1: 'O clap your hands, all ye ______; shout unto God with the voice of triumph.'
questions.correctAnswer: people
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:1 says, 'O clap your hands, all ye people; shout unto God with the voice of triumph.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 47:6: 'Sing praises to God, sing praises: sing praises unto our _______, sing praises.'
questions.correctAnswer: King
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:6 commands to sing praises unto our King.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 47 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 47 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 47, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God’s sovereignty?
options: God is a great King over all the earth who reigns with power
God allows nations to rule without interference
God is distant and uninvolved in earthly matters
God only cares about the righteous in secret
questions.correctAnswer: God is a great King over all the earth who reigns with power
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:2 declares God as a great King over all the earth, and verses 47:3 and 47:8 show His sovereign rule over nations and peoples, assuring believers of His control even in trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 47 teach us about praising God in our daily lives?
options: We should sing praises with understanding and shout with the voice of triumph
Praise should be quiet and only within the church building
Praising God is optional and only for special occasions
Praise is only for the priests and leaders
questions.correctAnswer: We should sing praises with understanding and shout with the voice of triumph
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:1, 6, and 7 emphasize clapping hands, shouting unto God, and singing praises with understanding, encouraging active and joyful worship as part of faithful living.

questions.question: A believer struggles with fear and doubts God’s power. According to Psalms 47, what truth about God would you share to encourage faith?
options: The LORD most high is terrible and mighty, subduing peoples and nations
God is weak and depends on humans to succeed
God’s power is limited to certain regions
God does not intervene in worldly affairs
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD most high is terrible and mighty, subduing peoples and nations
questions.explanation: Verse 47:2 describes God as 'terrible' in the sense of awe-inspiring power, and verse 47:3 explains He subdues peoples, showing His sovereign strength to inspire faith and trust.

questions.question: What does Psalms 47 teach about God’s role in giving inheritance and blessings to His people?
options: God chooses our inheritance, showing His love for Jacob
Inheritance is earned only by human effort
God does not concern Himself with earthly blessings
Inheritance is decided by the strongest nation
questions.correctAnswer: God chooses our inheritance, showing His love for Jacob
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:4 states that God chooses the inheritance for His people, the excellency of Jacob, indicating His active role in blessing and caring for His covenant people.

questions.question: How does the imagery of God ascending with a shout and trumpet sound (Psalms 47:5) encourage believers in worship and spiritual discipline?
options: It reminds believers to celebrate God’s victory with boldness and joy
It suggests worship should be quiet and subdued
It means worship is only for special festivals
It implies only priests can lead worship
questions.correctAnswer: It reminds believers to celebrate God’s victory with boldness and joy
questions.explanation: Verse 47:5 portrays God’s triumphant ascent with loud celebration, encouraging believers to worship with enthusiasm and confidence in His victory.

questions.question: A church member asks how to approach worship with wisdom. What guidance does Psalms 47 offer?
options: Sing praises with understanding because God is King of all the earth
Worship is only external singing without thought
Praise should be silent to avoid attention
questions.correctAnswer: Sing praises with understanding because God is King of all the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:7 teaches worship with understanding, highlighting the need for thoughtful and sincere praise recognizing God’s sovereignty.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 47, God’s reign is limited to Israel alone.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:8 states God reigns over the heathen and all the earth, showing His universal kingship beyond Israel.

questions.question: How does Psalms 47 encourage believers to maintain integrity and faith in community life?
options: By gathering princes and people together acknowledging God’s protection
By isolating from others to avoid conflict
By relying only on human strength and shields
By ignoring God’s role in leadership
questions.correctAnswer: By gathering princes and people together acknowledging God’s protection
questions.explanation: Verse 47:9 highlights the gathering of leaders and people recognizing God as the protector, encouraging faithfulness and unity under God’s care.

questions.question: A parent wants to teach their children about God’s power and holiness. Which verse in Psalms 47 would best help them explain this truth?
options: God sitteth upon the throne of his holiness
God is silent and hidden from view
God is like a distant king
questions.correctAnswer: God sitteth upon the throne of his holiness
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:8 describes God’s holiness and sovereign rule, a foundational truth to teach children about God’s nature and authority.

questions.question: What practical encouragement about perseverance through trials can we find in Psalms 47?
options: God subdues nations and gives us victory, so we can trust Him in struggles
Trials mean God has abandoned us
We must rely only on ourselves to overcome difficulties
God’s power is limited to spiritual matters alone
questions.correctAnswer: God subdues nations and gives us victory, so we can trust Him in struggles
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:3 shows God subdues peoples under us, symbolizing His power to grant victory and encourage perseverance during trials.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 47 teaches that God’s protection is symbolized by the shields of the earth.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:9 mentions that 'the shields of the earth belong unto God,' symbolizing His protective power over the world.

questions.question: How does Psalms 47 inspire generosity and stewardship among believers?
options: By reminding them that God chooses their inheritance and blesses them
By encouraging hoarding wealth for personal gain
By telling believers to ignore earthly blessings
By suggesting wealth is irrelevant to faith
questions.correctAnswer: By reminding them that God chooses their inheritance and blesses them
questions.explanation: Verse 47:4 shows God’s choice of inheritance for His people, inspiring gratitude and responsible stewardship of blessings.

questions.question: In Psalms 47, what action is encouraged for the sons of Korah as a form of spiritual discipline?
options: Clap your hands and shout unto God with the voice of triumph
Remain silent and avoid public worship
questions.correctAnswer: Clap your hands and shout unto God with the voice of triumph
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:1 calls for clapping hands and shouting to God joyfully, demonstrating an active spiritual discipline of worship.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'God is gone up with a _______, the LORD with the sound of a trumpet.'
questions.correctAnswer: shout
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:5 states God 'is gone up with a shout,' symbolizing triumphant and joyful worship.

questions.question: How can Psalms 47 guide believers in evangelism and being a witness to others?
options: By proclaiming God’s universal kingship and inviting all peoples to praise Him
By keeping faith private and avoiding public declaration
By focusing only on one’s own spiritual growth
By competing with other religions to prove superiority
questions.correctAnswer: By proclaiming God’s universal kingship and inviting all peoples to praise Him
questions.explanation: Verses 47:7 and 47:8 show God’s reign over all the earth and peoples, encouraging believers to share this truth widely as a witness.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 47 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 47.

questions.question: What is the primary action the psalmist urges all people to perform in Psalms 47:1?
options: Clap your hands and shout unto God with the voice of triumph
Sing a lament for the nations
questions.correctAnswer: Clap your hands and shout unto God with the voice of triumph
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:1 commands all people to clap their hands and shout unto God with a voice of triumph, emphasizing communal praise and victory.

questions.question: According to Psalms 47:2, how is the LORD most high described in relation to the earth?
options: A great King over all the earth
A distant deity watching from afar
questions.correctAnswer: A great King over all the earth
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly calls the LORD 'a great King over all the earth,' denoting universal sovereignty.

questions.question: Which nations or groups does Psalms 47:3 say the LORD will subdue?
options: The people under us and the nations under our feet
questions.correctAnswer: The people under us and the nations under our feet
questions.explanation: This verse refers to God's subduing the peoples and nations under the psalmist's group, showing divine empowerment and conquest.

questions.question: What inheritance is chosen for the people according to Psalms 47:4?
options: The excellency of Jacob whom he loved
questions.correctAnswer: The excellency of Jacob whom he loved
questions.explanation: The verse highlights God's selection of the inheritance associated with Jacob, emphasizing a covenantal theme.

questions.question: The phrase 'God is gone up with a shout' in Psalms 47:5 is an example of what literary device?
questions.correctAnswer: Typology foreshadowing Christ's ascension
questions.explanation: The language of God ascending with a shout and trumpet sound foreshadows the New Testament depiction of Christ's ascension (Acts 1:9-11).

questions.question: According to Psalms 47:6, what is repeated three times to emphasize the act of worship?
questions.correctAnswer: Sing praises
questions.explanation: The triple repetition of 'sing praises' serves as a poetic parallelism intensifying the call to worship.

questions.question: How does Psalms 47:7 describe the manner in which believers should sing praises to God?
questions.correctAnswer: With understanding
questions.explanation: The psalmist commands singing praises with understanding, implying informed and heartfelt worship.

questions.question: What throne does God sit upon according to Psalms 47:8?
questions.correctAnswer: The throne of his holiness
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states that God sits upon the throne of his holiness, emphasizing divine purity and sovereignty.

questions.question: Who are gathered together in Psalms 47:9, and what do the shields of the earth belong to?
options: The princes of the people and the people of the God of Abraham; the shields belong to God
The kings of the nations; the shields belong to the armies
The priests of the temple; the shields belong to the temple guards
The merchants of the city; the shields belong to the city gates
questions.correctAnswer: The princes of the people and the people of the God of Abraham; the shields belong to God
questions.explanation: The verse gathers leaders and the covenant people, affirming God's possession of the shields of the earth, symbolizing protection and authority.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 47 calls for a silent, contemplative worship rather than vocal and physical expressions of praise.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:1 and 6 emphasize clapping hands, shouting, and singing praises, which are vocal and physical expressions of worship.

questions.question: The emphasis on God as 'King of all the earth' in Psalms 47:7 connects to which Old Testament theme?
options: God’s universal sovereignty over all nations
God’s role as a local tribal deity
questions.correctAnswer: God’s universal sovereignty over all nations
questions.explanation: The psalm reflects the Old Testament theme of God as sovereign King over all nations, transcending Israel’s boundaries (see also Psalm 93:1).

questions.question: The shout and trumpet mentioned in Psalms 47:5 are culturally significant in the ancient Near East because they often signified what?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine kingship and military victory
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, shouts and trumpet blasts were common symbols announcing a king’s arrival or military triumph, aligning with this psalm’s themes.

questions.question: In Psalms 47:4, the phrase 'the excellency of Jacob whom he loved' is best understood as which type of literary device?
options: A covenantal allusion affirming God’s special relationship with Israel
An ironic statement about Jacob's failures
questions.correctAnswer: A covenantal allusion affirming God’s special relationship with Israel
questions.explanation: This phrase recalls God’s covenant love for Jacob (Israel), emphasizing divine election and favor.

questions.question: Which New Testament event is foreshadowed by God 'going up with a shout' in Psalms 47:5?
questions.correctAnswer: The Ascension of Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: The imagery of God ascending with a shout parallels the Ascension of Christ described in Acts 1:9-11.

questions.question: How does the gathering of 'the princes of the people' in Psalms 47:9 reflect ancient Israel’s socio-political structure?
options: It shows the unity of tribal leaders under God’s sovereignty
It indicates a division between priests and kings
It suggests the exile of leaders to foreign lands
It implies a rebellion against God
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the unity of tribal leaders under God’s sovereignty
questions.explanation: The gathering of princes and the people of God demonstrates a unification under divine authority typical of ancient Israel’s covenant community.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 47 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 47 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 47:2, what attribute of the LORD is emphasized?
options: He is a great King over all the earth
He is merciful and slow to anger
He is a healer of all diseases
He is a provider of daily needs
questions.correctAnswer: He is a great King over all the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:2 states 'For the LORD most high is terrible; he is a great King over all the earth,' emphasizing God's sovereign kingship. This aligns with 1 Timothy 6:15 which calls God the 'King of kings,' Revelation 19:16 where Jesus is called 'King of kings and Lord of lords,' Isaiah 6:5 which reveres God's holiness and majesty, and Daniel 4:37 where God’s dominion is declared everlasting.

questions.question: What is the response of the people to God as described in Psalms 47:1?
options: O clap your hands; shout unto God with the voice of triumph
questions.correctAnswer: O clap your hands; shout unto God with the voice of triumph
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:1 commands the people to express praise actively by clapping hands and shouting triumphantly. This joyful corporate praise corresponds with Hebrews 12:28 where we are urged to offer acceptable service with reverence and awe, Psalm 98:4 which calls for joyful noise, and Psalm 150:6 which exhorts everything that has breath to praise the LORD.

questions.question: In Psalms 47:5, what imagery is used to describe God's ascension?
options: God is gone up with a shout, the LORD with the sound of a trumpet
God rides on a chariot of fire
God walks on the wings of the wind
God appears in a pillar of cloud
questions.correctAnswer: God is gone up with a shout, the LORD with the sound of a trumpet
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:5 uses the imagery of a shout and trumpet to depict God's ascension, symbolizing triumph and divine authority. This is consistent with 1 Thessalonians 4:16 where the Lord descends with a shout and trumpet, Exodus 19:16 where trumpet sounds accompany God's presence, and Revelation 8:6 which describes trumpet blasts heralding divine actions.

questions.question: According to Psalms 47:4, what has God chosen as an inheritance for His people?
options: The excellency of Jacob whom he loved
The land of Egypt as a refuge
The cities of Babylon and Nineveh
questions.correctAnswer: The excellency of Jacob whom he loved
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:4 reveals God's sovereign choice of the heritage given to His people, specifically highlighting Jacob’s excellency. This reflects Romans 9:13 where God loved Jacob and hated Esau, Genesis 28:13 where the promise to Jacob is reaffirmed, and Deuteronomy 32:9 which speaks of Israel as God's portion.

questions.question: What does Psalms 47:7 instruct believers to do when praising God?
questions.correctAnswer: Sing ye praises with understanding
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:7 commands that praise be offered with understanding, implying a conscious and thoughtful worship. This principle is echoed in 1 Corinthians 14:15 which encourages singing with the spirit and understanding, Colossians 3:16 which enjoins teaching and admonishing through psalms, and Ephesians 5:19 which urges singing to God in your heart.

questions.question: Who does Psalms 47:8 say God reigns over?
questions.correctAnswer: The heathen
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:8 states 'God reigneth over the heathen,' highlighting His universal sovereignty beyond Israel. This theme is supported by Psalm 22:28 where the earth is given to the children of men, Romans 3:29 which says God is the God of the Gentiles also, and Revelation 15:4 which praises God’s reign over all nations.

questions.question: According to Psalms 47:3, what will God do concerning the nations?
options: He shall subdue the people under us, and the nations under our feet
He shall destroy all the nations utterly
He shall bless the nations without judgment
He shall remain silent concerning the nations
questions.correctAnswer: He shall subdue the people under us, and the nations under our feet
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:3 declares God’s subjugation of nations under His people, showing divine empowerment for dominion. This is consistent with Genesis 1:28 where mankind is given dominion over the earth, Psalm 2:8-9 which promises rule over nations, and Matthew 28:18 where Christ has all authority in heaven and earth.

questions.question: What does Psalms 47:9 reveal about the 'shields of the earth'?
options: They belong to kings and princes
They belong to the armies of men
questions.correctAnswer: They belong unto God
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:9 affirms that the 'shields of the earth' belong to God, symbolizing His protection and sovereignty over all worldly powers. This matches Isaiah 51:16 where God’s word is a shield, Psalm 18:2 describing God as a shield and stronghold, and Ephesians 6:16 which calls believers to take up the shield of faith.

questions.question: Who are gathered together according to Psalms 47:9?
options: The princes of the people, even the people of the God of Abraham
The kings of the nations against Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The princes of the people, even the people of the God of Abraham
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:9 describes a gathering of leaders and the people associated with God of Abraham, showing a unified assembly under God’s sovereignty. This corresponds with Hebrews 11:8-12 which praises faith of Abraham’s descendants, Genesis 17:7-8 where God promises to be God of Abraham’s seed, and Acts 3:25 that refers to the blessing of all families through Abraham.

questions.question: What title is repeatedly given to God in Psalms 47?
questions.correctAnswer: King of all the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 47 calls God 'King of all the earth' multiple times (verses 2, 7, 8), emphasizing His universal kingship. This is echoed in Revelation 15:3, 1 Timothy 1:17 which calls God the King eternal, James 1:17 referring to the Father of lights who is unchanging, and Isaiah 33:22 declaring God as judge, lawgiver, and king.

questions.question: What is the significance of the trumpet sound mentioned in Psalms 47:5?
options: It signifies God's triumphant ascension and authority
It calls the people to war against enemies
It signals the start of a festival
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies God's triumphant ascension and authority
questions.explanation: The trumpet in Psalms 47:5 symbolizes divine triumph and authority, consistent with 1 Corinthians 15:52 where the trumpet signals resurrection, Joshua 6:20 where trumpets accompany God’s victory, and Revelation 8:2 where trumpets herald God’s judgments.

questions.question: How does Psalms 47:6 characterize the manner of worship?
options: Sing praises to God, sing praises
questions.correctAnswer: Sing praises to God, sing praises
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:6 emphasizes vocal, joyful singing in worship, a common biblical motif found in Ephesians 5:19, Psalm 96:1 which calls to sing a new song, Hebrews 2:12 quoting the praise of God in songs, and Psalm 33:2 that encourages praise with harp and lute.

questions.question: What does Psalms 47:8 imply about God's throne?
options: God sitteth upon the throne of his holiness
God's throne is on Mount Zion
God's throne is made of gold
God's throne is surrounded by angels
questions.correctAnswer: God sitteth upon the throne of his holiness
questions.explanation: Psalms 47:8 states God sits upon the throne of his holiness, underscoring God's pure, sovereign rule. This is reflected in Isaiah 6:1 where the Lord is seen on a high and lifted throne, Revelation 4:2 describing God’s throne in heaven, and Hebrews 12:28 calling for reverence before the holy God.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'Selah' in Psalms 47:4 likely indicate in the context of worship?
options: A pause for reflection on God's chosen inheritance
A call to war against enemies
An instruction to fast and pray
questions.correctAnswer: A pause for reflection on God's chosen inheritance
questions.explanation: The term 'Selah' in Psalms 47:4 is generally understood as a pause or interlude inviting reflection on the previous statement about God's choice of inheritance. This is consistent with its usage throughout Psalms (e.g., Psalms 3:2, Psalms 24:6), allowing worshippers to meditate on God’s attributes, as seen in Lamentations 3:41 and Habakkuk 3:3.

questions.question: Which group is identified as the intended audience of Psalms 47 in its heading?
questions.correctAnswer: The sons of Korah
questions.explanation: The heading of Psalms 47 identifies it as 'A Psalm for the sons of Korah,' a group of temple singers and musicians (Psalms 47:1). This is supported by other Psalms attributed to them (e.g., Psalms 42, 44), 1 Chronicles 6:31-48 which lists the Korahites as temple musicians, and their role in worship as in 2 Chronicles 20:19.
